LRUCache

Type: Concrete Class

Description

LRUCache<K, V> which extends AbstractCache is an in-memory cache that evicts the Least Recently Used item when it reaches capacity. It uses a combination of a HashMap and a custom doubly linked list to support O(1) time complexity for both get and put operations. This class extends AbstractCache and provides LRU eviction logic.

Use Cases

  • Web server or API response caching
  • Application-level memory cache
  • GPU texture or browser resource caching

Method Summary

Return Type Method Description Time Complexity
V get(K key) Returns the value and updates its usage as most recently used. O(1)
void put(K key, V value) Inserts or updates a key-value entry; evicts if needed. O(1)
int size() Returns number of entries in the cache. O(1)
boolean contains(K key) Checks if key is present in the cache. O(1)
void remove(K key) Removes the given key from the cache. O(1)
void clear() Clears all key-value entries. O(n)

Algorithm Details

The LRUCache (Least Recently Used Cache) evicts the entry that was accessed least recently:

  • Access Tracking: On every get or put, the accessed node is moved to the front of a doubly linked list to mark it as most recently used.
  • Eviction Policy: When capacity is exceeded, the least recently used (tail) node is evicted from the list and removed from the map.
  • Internal Data Structures:
    • Map<K, Node<K, V>> for constant-time key lookup
    • DoublyLinkedList<K, V> to maintain access order in O(1) time

Space Complexity: O(n), where n is the maximum number of entries in the cache. Each entry is stored both in the map and as a node in the doubly linked list.

Sample Usage


LRUCache<String, Integer> cache = new LRUCache<>(2);
cache.put("A", 1);
cache.put("B", 2);
cache.get("A"); // Access A -> now A is most recently used
cache.put("C", 3); // Evicts B (least recently used)
System.out.println(cache.contains("B")); // false
System.out.println(cache.get("A")); // 1
System.out.println(cache.get("C")); // 3
